results.title: 'Moomba' 1974 - 'Float parade' thru' the city
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a public cultural event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Monarch royals who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film shows footage of the 1974 Moomba parade through Melbourne, filmed at the corner of Victoria and Swanston Streets, opposite the City Baths. The parade begins with a marching band, followed by Disney cartoon characters Captain Hook and Mr Smee from Peter Pan, and Goofy. The 1974 Queen of Moomba Marianne Perrott appears on a decorative blue float, seated in a throne behind the distinctive white swan.

The camera then follows the rest of the parade, featuring entertainers, celebrities and characters such as Humphrey B. Bear, Daryl Somers and Ossie Ostrich, and a particularly impressive display of decorated floats and performances. Some of the notable appearances include Waltons department store, a group of Michelin men, the new Holden Torana with a sign reading “just in time for Moomba”, ATV0 ‘Australia’s Action Station’, Bendigo Pottery featuring a potter making ceramics on a wheel, Jewel Box, the Royal Children’s Hospital Pied Pipers, a Ukrainian Easter float, a Chinese dragon dance, Whittlesea District Mini Bike Club, and the Hungarian Square Dancing Association.

results.title: Chari-dogs of Fire
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @andersonvilien's Twitter feed
results.brief_description: What cinematic trope is more iconic (and more replicated) than a good old-fashioned, dramatic slow-motion running scene? Combine it with a dramatic musical accompaniment (here, Wagner’s Ride of the Valkyries plays that role to perfection) and an eyewatering number of cute dogs, and you have the recipe for the perfect viral pet video - one that ends, fittingly, in glorious chaos.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

What cinematic trope is more iconic (and more replicated) than a good old-fashioned, dramatic slow-motion running scene? Combine it with a dramatic musical accompaniment (here, Wagner’s “Ride of the Valkyries” plays that role to perfection) and an eyewatering number of cute dogs, and you have the recipe for the perfect viral pet video - one that ends, fittingly, in glorious chaos.

results.title: Get you a Prime Minister who can do both (sing the same verse of April Sun In Cuba twice)
results.brief_description: In an effort to rehabilitate his image after a disastrous week in politics – including shelving his signature religious discrimination bill and what some saw as a disingenuous apology on sexual assault in parliament – Prime Minister Scott Morrison hosted a lengthy interview with 60 Minutes Australia. Promos for the episode quickly circulated on social media, with users lambasting Scott Morrison’s attempt to project a demeanour of goofy familiarity and his peculiar choice of strumming a ukulele – an instrument most popular in Hawaii, where Morrison holidayed at the height of summer bushfires in 2019/20.
results.title_for_label: Get you a Prime Minister who can do both (sing the same verse of April Sun In Cuba twice)
results.description: In an effort to rehabilitate his image after a disastrous week in politics – including shelving his signature religious discrimination bill and what some saw as a disingenuous apology on sexual assault in parliament – Prime Minister Scott Morrison hosted a lengthy interview with 60 Minutes Australia. Promos for the episode quickly circulated on social media, with users lambasting Scott Morrison’s attempt to project a demeanour of goofy familiarity and his peculiar choice of strumming a ukulele – an instrument most popular in Hawaii, where Morrison holidayed at the height of summer bushfires in 2019/20. As you can see below, the footage was remixed by social-media users, who superimposed the footage on different backgrounds, including raging bushfires, while others changed the song from Dragon’s “April Sun in Cuba” to Radiohead’s “Creep” and Denis Leary’s “Asshole”.
description_for_label: In an effort to rehabilitate his image after a disastrous week in politics – including shelving his signature religious discrimination bill and what some saw as a disingenuous apology on sexual assault in parliament – Prime Minister Scott Morrison hosted a lengthy interview with 60 Minutes Australia. Promos for the episode quickly circulated on social media, with users lambasting Scott Morrison’s attempt to project a demeanour of goofy familiarity and his peculiar choice of strumming a ukulele – an instrument most popular in Hawaii, where Morrison holidayed at the height of summer bushfires in 2019/20.

results.title: Feel absolutely confused and heartbroken about #Neighbours
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @mr_sjpatterson’s Twitter account
results.brief_description: Fans respond to the sad news that the soap Neighbours will be axed after nearly four decades. The UK’s Channel 5, the show’s biggest financial backer in recent years, has confirmed it will not renew the program. The hashtag #SaveNeighbours has been trending on social media since news broke.
results.description: Fans respond to the sad news that the soap Neighbours will be axed after nearly four decades. The UK’s Channel 5, the show’s biggest financial backer in recent years, has confirmed it will not renew the program. The hashtag #SaveNeighbours has been trending on social media since news broke.

results.title: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns Ash Barty Australian Open champion
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @AustralianOpen Twitter post
results.brief_description: Ngarigo woman and world number one in women’s singles tennis, Ash Barty, accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in her Australian Open finals match against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.
results.title_for_label: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns champion Ash Barty at the Australian Open
results.description: Ngarigo woman and women’s tennis world number one Ash Barty accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in the Australian Open final against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.

The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.

results.title: Grace Tame visits the Prime Minister
results.brief_description: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

Meanwhile, a huge swath of the internet came out in support of Tame’s directness – with stills from the footage shared across social media – likening her demeanour to their feelings towards the Coalition government.

Throughout her tenure as Australian of the Year, Tame has been vocal about the government’s handling of sexual abuse allegations and its treatment of survivors. In April of 2021, when asked about Scott Morrison’s ‘as a father’ response to rape allegations made by Brittany Higgins – which some believe he didn’t take seriously until “viewing it from the lens of being a father of daughters” – Tame responded: “It shouldn’t take children to have a conscience. And actually, on top of that, having children doesn’t guarantee a conscience.” Like this most recent interaction with the Prime Minister, that clip also went viral on the internet, helping solidify Tame’s position as a courageous advocate for sexual assault survivors and a moral champion at a time when many see Australia’s leaders as lacking both courage and morals.

As Imogen Champagne writes in Crikey:, “Conservatives have been trying to silence Grace Tame all year. Now she’s finally given them silence and they can’t shut up about it.”
description_for_label: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

results.title: The Making of Florence - Episode 4
results.brief_description:
Expertly blending the visual novel and gaming genres, Florence illustrates one year in the life of a young woman in Melbourne as she falls in love, breaks her daily routine and follows her creative passion.

Developed by Australian craft games studio Mountains, Florence uses innovative gameplay mechanics to represent social interactions. The emotions of the poignant narrative are rendered through tapping and swiping minigames, making them all the more touching.

This video covers the leadup to the first public look of Florence at PAX Australia 2017 of the first public look of Florence. In it, Mountains reflects on about its reception by the public and the game’s upcoming release.

results.title: The Making of Florence - Episode 3
results.brief_description:
Expertly blending the visual novel and gaming genres, Florence illustrates one year in the life of a young woman in Melbourne as she falls in love, breaks her daily routine and follows her creative passion.

Developed by Australian craft games studio Mountains, Florence uses innovative gameplay mechanics to represent social interactions. The emotions of the poignant narrative are rendered through tapping and swiping minigames, making them all the more touching.

These interviews focus on how Mountains developed the musical score and tone of the game, working with game composer Kevin Penkin. This video features behind the scenes footage of the soundtrack’s recording session.

results.title: The Making of Florence - Episode 2
results.brief_description:
Expertly blending the visual novel and gaming genres, Florence illustrates one year in the life of a young woman in Melbourne as she falls in love, breaks her daily routine and follows her creative passion.

Developed by Australian craft games studio Mountains, Florence uses innovative gameplay mechanics to represent social interactions. The emotions of the poignant narrative are rendered through tapping and swiping minigames, making them all the more touching.

These interviews cover the overall creation process for Florence, focusing on how the developer creates a cohesive story through discussions, storyboarding, the art style, the music and the characters.
